Title: Can AI companies revive downtown SF? Here's what economists say - San Francisco Chronicle
description: There is hope that AI companies based in San Francisco could boost the cityâs economy and revitalize the downtown area, but some economists arenât so sure.
og:description: There is hope that AI companies based in San Francisco could boost the cityâs economy and revitalize the downtown area, but some economists arenât so sure.
twitter:description: Job posting data shows the San Francisco metropolitan statistical area steadily losing its...
author: [{'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Chase DiFeliciantonio', 'jobTitle': 'Reporter', 'url': 'https://www.sfchronicle.com/author/chase-difeliciantonio/'}]
image: {'@type': 'imageObject', 'width': 2048, 'height': 1365, 'url': 'https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/31/32/13/23438063/3/rawImage.jpg', 'thumbnailUrl': 'https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/31/32/13/23438063/3/square_small.jpg', 'caption': 'The San Francisco metropolitan statistical area steadily is losing its share of artificial intelligence job postings, data shows.'}
headline: Can AI companies revive downtown SF? Here's what economists say
article text: The San Francisco metropolitan statistical area steadily is losing its share of artificial intelligence job postings, data shows.Carlos Avila Gonzalez, Staff Photographer / The ChronicleThe buzz in recent weeks over leaps in artificial intelligence, or AI, technology has caused venture capitalists and marquee companies like Microsoft to pour billions of dollars into the trending industry. And with many of the most recognizable AI companies based in San Francisco, there are hopes that the rising industry could shift the cityâs fortunes and not just revitalize its tech sector, but help fill empty downtown streets, offices and shops with the next wave of tech workers whose spending could filter through the rest of the cityâs economy.But some economists arenât so sure.On one hand, overall hiring in San Franciscoâs tech sector in recent months has been flat. That is a mostly positive sign, according to city data and San Francisco Chief Economist Ted Egan, especially since ongoing layoffs have battered companies based in the city in recent weeks and months.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adBut job posting data aggregated from thousands of hiring sites nationally by jobs site ZipRecruiter shows the San Francisco metropolitan statistical area steadily losing its share of job postings in the burgeoning AI field. Itâs not entirely clear where those jobs might be located from the data. Some postings could be located in other cities, or a remote role might not have a location tied to it at all.ZipRecruiterâs analysis shows that the San Francisco areaâs average share of active U.S. AI online job postings peaked during the past three years at 7.35% in May 2020. The most recent numbers show that number at just under 3% in January, having mostly dropped month to month since the high point.Embed 5022278Z-1675466948160 San Francisco's share of U.S. AI job postings on ZipRecruiter, 2020-23Thatâs a worrying sign for the city and the region, said ZipRecruiter Chief Economist Julia Pollak.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adâSan Francisco has kind of gotten the rawest deal of all,â Pollak said. Whereas the city once had the heaviest concentration of tech jobs nationally, âgeography has become so much less important than before the pandemic.â The huge shift to full or partial remote work has allowed companies, even if they are based here, to hire people anywhere, she added.âIt doesnât seem likely that San Francisco is going to manage to claw back those jobs,â she said.A city analysis from April last year showed that 33% of local office workers would probably do their jobs remotely, up from an estimate of 15% in January 2022.More For YouAre tech layoffs a sign of looming Bay Area recession? Hereâs what experts sayEconomists and experts said while the layoffs are disruptive, they donât tell the whole...Hereâs how many S.F. employees were laid off by SalesforceThe company said in state filings that the layoffs would commence effective March 24And that could have profound effects for the city, which has continued to lose residents, and the ongoing recovery of its economy.âOnce you have a critical mass of tech workers leaving San Francisco and a critical mass of people hired elsewhere, you canât go back,â Pollak said. âWith people leaving the area, there are more properties and offices vacant,â which has led to less foot traffic and economic activity in places like downtown, she said.San Francisco saw a nearly 46% office occupancy rate during the last full week of January according to office card-swipe company Kastle Systems, slowly creeping up from where it has hovered, around 40%, for months.San Francisco city data shows that remote work has led to continually rising office vacancies, however, which were above 25% in the fourth quarter of last year.But Egan, the cityâs chief economist, was quick to differentiate job postings from actual hires.âAttempts to hire are not necessarily net new growth,â he said, referring to the postings aggregated by ZipRecruiter, which looked for keywords in job listings to pick out AI and machine-learning roles.He noted that companies in San Francisco and elsewhere may also be adding AI keywords to their job postings to make them appear more attractive, because the industry is seeing so much interest right now.âThe important context is that job listings can be a leading indicator for the labor market,â Egan said. âLike all leading indicators, they come with an element of inaccuracy.âThe city, in its monthly economic analysis, does not differentiate AI jobs from tech more broadly, Egan said.That is despite seemingly daily stories of tech companies large and small cutting hundreds or thousands of jobs.San Franciscoâs most recent monthly report shows that the unemployment rate dropped to 2% in January. The report noted that while the information sector, which includes many tech roles, lost jobs on a net basis, growth in professional and technical services, which also includes some tech as well as health care and retail trade, more than made up for the loss.âThe real question is, given all the layoffs, why isnât tech employment dropping faster?â Egan said.Some reasons could be that not all layoffs at companies based in the city affect workers based there. There are also frequently lag times between layoff announcements and actual separations, Egan said. Itâs also likely that people are being laid off but finding other jobs.Federal government statistics released last week showed that jobs in professional and business services jumped nationally last month by 82,000, half of that number in the professional, scientific and technical services.Egan said it was difficult to say, if indeed the cityâs share of AI jobs was trending down, why that might be, but he cast doubt on San Francisco-based companies offering enough remote positions to meaningfully drive down the number of jobs in that industry in the San Francisco area.Whatever the data says, some AI industry luminaries remain bullish on the city, despite its shortcomings.In a recent tweet, Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, whose ChatGPT product has impressed users with its fluent responses if not its accuracy, called San Francisco the âcenter of the AI revolution.ââS.F. remains super relevant for the next decade,â Altman said.Chase DiFeliciantonio is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. Email: chase.difeliciantonio@sfchronicle.com Twitter: @ChaseDiFelice
articleBody: The buzz in recent weeks over leaps in artificial intelligence, or AI, technology has caused venture capitalists and marquee companies like Microsoft to pour billions of dollars into the trending industry. And with many of the most recognizable AI companies based in San Francisco, there are hopes that the rising industry could shift the cityâs fortunes and not just revitalize its tech sector, but help fill empty downtown streets, offices and shops with the next wave of tech workers whose spending could filter through the rest of the cityâs economy. But some economists arenât so sure. On one hand, overall hiring in San Franciscoâs tech sector in recent months has been flat. That is a mostly positive sign, according to city data and San Francisco Chief Economist Ted Egan, especially since ongoing layoffs have battered companies based in the city in recent weeks and months. But job posting data aggregated from thousands of hiring sites nationally by jobs site ZipRecruiter shows the San Francisco metropolitan statistical area steadily losing its share of job postings in the burgeoning AI field. Itâs not entirely clear where those jobs might be located from the data. Some postings could be located in other cities, or a remote role might not have a location tied to it at all. ZipRecruiterâs analysis shows that the San Francisco areaâs average share of active U.S. AI online job postings peaked during the past three years at 7.35% in May 2020. The most recent numbers show that number at just under 3% in January, having mostly dropped month to month since the high point. Embed 5022278Z-1675466948160 San Francisco's share of U.S. AI job postings on ZipRecruiter, 2020-23 Thatâs a worrying sign for the city and the region, said ZipRecruiter Chief Economist Julia Pollak. âSan Francisco has kind of gotten the rawest deal of all,â Pollak said. Whereas the city once had the heaviest concentration of tech jobs nationally, âgeography has become so much less important than before the pandemic.â The huge shift to full or partial remote work has allowed companies, even if they are based here, to hire people anywhere, she added. âIt doesnât seem likely that San Francisco is going to manage to claw back those jobs,â she said. A city analysis from April last year showed that 33% of local office workers would probably do their jobs remotely, up from an estimate of 15% in January 2022. And that could have profound effects for the city, which has continued to lose residents, and the ongoing recovery of its economy. âOnce you have a critical mass of tech workers leaving San Francisco and a critical mass of people hired elsewhere, you canât go back,â Pollak said. âWith people leaving the area, there are more properties and offices vacant,â which has led to less foot traffic and economic activity in places like downtown, she said. San Francisco saw a nearly 46% office occupancy rate during the last full week of January according to office card-swipe company Kastle Systems, slowly creeping up from where it has hovered, around 40%, for months. San Francisco city data shows that remote work has led to continually rising office vacancies, however, which were above 25% in the fourth quarter of last year. But Egan, the cityâs chief economist, was quick to differentiate job postings from actual hires. âAttempts to hire are not necessarily net new growth,â he said, referring to the postings aggregated by ZipRecruiter, which looked for keywords in job listings to pick out AI and machine-learning roles. He noted that companies in San Francisco and elsewhere may also be adding AI keywords to their job postings to make them appear more attractive, because the industry is seeing so much interest right now. âThe important context is that job listings can be a leading indicator for the labor market,â Egan said. âLike all leading indicators, they come with an element of inaccuracy.â The city, in its monthly economic analysis, does not differentiate AI jobs from tech more broadly, Egan said. That is despite seemingly daily stories of tech companies large and small cutting hundreds or thousands of jobs. San Franciscoâs most recent monthly report shows that the unemployment rate dropped to 2% in January. The report noted that while the information sector, which includes many tech roles, lost jobs on a net basis, growth in professional and technical services, which also includes some tech as well as health care and retail trade, more than made up for the loss. âThe real question is, given all the layoffs, why isnât tech employment dropping faster?â Egan said. Some reasons could be that not all layoffs at companies based in the city affect workers based there. There are also frequently lag times between layoff announcements and actual separations, Egan said. Itâs also likely that people are being laid off but finding other jobs. Federal government statistics released last week showed that jobs in professional and business services jumped nationally last month by 82,000, half of that number in the professional, scientific and technical services. Egan said it was difficult to say, if indeed the cityâs share of AI jobs was trending down, why that might be, but he cast doubt on San Francisco-based companies offering enough remote positions to meaningfully drive down the number of jobs in that industry in the San Francisco area. Whatever the data says, some AI industry luminaries remain bullish on the city, despite its shortcomings. In a recent tweet, Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, whose ChatGPT product has impressed users with its fluent responses if not its accuracy, called San Francisco the âcenter of the AI revolution.â âS.F. remains super relevant for the next decade,â Altman said. Chase DiFeliciantonio is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. Email: chase.difeliciantonio@sfchronicle.com Twitter: @ChaseDiFelice

article text:
Academic Integrity and Artificial Intelligence
What students need to know



February 10, 2023Â âÂ 
Youâve probably used AI tools without even knowing it â Grammarly, Google Translate, Quillbot, Jasper, auto-complete and grammar checker. But now, there are more sophisticated AI tools available, like ChatGPT andÂ DALL â¢ E, that are able to create content in ways never seen before. ChatGPT has attracted a lot of attention recently, including commentary from celebrities and well-known authorities. Actor Ryan Reynolds used Chat GPT to write a script, musician Nick Cave wrote a viral blog post on why AI could never replace artists, and one of theÂ largest scientific, academic journalsÂ not accepting ChatGPT as authors in any publications.
Francois Jordaan, a UM Academic Integrity Specialist, says,Â  âStudents are asking if and how they can use these new AI tools to compete coursework. For example, students want to know if they can use these tools for inspiration, to get started or as a reference guide? Or, can they submit parts of AI-generated work if the context allows? If so, how do they cite it? Does using AI allow them to still work with integrity?â Jordaan explains that, âAs with other forms of collaboration, the lines between appropriate and inappropriate can get blurred. The answers arenât always black or white and context is everything.â
Here are some guiding principles for maintaining academic integrity in relation to artificial intelligence..

AI does not replace your own thinking, analysis, or judgment. Using AI inappropriately doesnât demonstrate your understanding of a topic and it doesnât help you learn the skills that are expected of you both within the classroom and in the workplace.
Whether or not AI use is appropriate depends on your instructor. Unless you are asked to use AI on a course assignment, assume you are not allowed to use it.
AI can be detected. There are tools that can detect AI produced content. Your instructors will assess you work based on their expertise, the learning objectives of the course and comparisons to your previous work.
If you have used AI without your instructorâs permission, you are at risk of facing an allegation of academic misconduct. A finding of academic misconduct has academic and personal consequences, including lowering your GPA, delaying your graduation and notations on your transcript. If in doubt whether AI is permitted â remember IF YOU NEED TO KNOW, ASK.
AI-generated content can be redundant, inaccurate and repetitive at best, and offensive or biased at worst. Remember that whatever you submit for a course assignment is your full and ultimate responsibility.
If you are permitted to use AI, you must cite it.

Staff from the Academic Learning Centre will be available to help you understand Artificial Intelligence and how it applies to Academic Integrity on the main floor of UMSU University Centre on February 15 and 16 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. There will be games and prizes as well as Valentines candy, so come check it out.
